topic: Implementing a rewards and recognition program to motivate and engage employees
always add the '@validate' decorator from the 'pedantic' module to all methods
session_eval_query: Library class with add books and remove books methods
sessions.text:
Djibril: Hi Jorge, it's great to finally meet you in person. I'm Djibril, your mentor here at CHEETAH. I oversee the software engineering team, and I'll be guiding you through your internship. How are you settling in so far?

Jorge: It's an honor to meet you, Djibril. I'm excited to be here and eager to learn. The team has been very welcoming, and I'm getting a good feel for the company culture. I think I'm settling in well.

Djibril: That's wonderful to hear. At CHEETAH, we prioritize employee engagement and believe in recognizing talent. One of our key initiatives is implementing a robust rewards and recognition program. It's a great way to motivate and engage our talented engineers, don't you think?

Jorge: Absolutely! A recognition program can boost morale and create a positive work environment. It encourages employees to go the extra mile and fosters a culture of innovation and creativity. I think it's a fantastic idea.

Djibril: Great! As you'll soon discover, we like to stay ahead of the curve here. Now, let's dive into some of the specifics. One of our goals is to integrate a points-based reward system. Employees can earn points through various achievements, such as completing projects, participating in training, or providing exceptional customer service. These points can then be redeemed for rewards, like gift cards, company merchandise, or even paid time off.

Jorge: That sounds like a comprehensive approach. It gives employees a sense of agency and allows them to work towards tangible goals. I presume there's also a digital platform or an app involved where employees can track their points and redeem rewards?

Djibril: Exactly, Jorge. You're catching on quickly. We're developing an internal platform that will serve as a one-stop shop for all things related to the rewards program. Employees can log in, view their point balance, browse available rewards, and redeem them instantly. We want to make the process as seamless and engaging as possible.

Jorge: That's impressive! I can see how this would enhance the employee experience. Are there any specific features or challenges that you've come across so far in developing this platform?

Djibril: Well, one of the key considerations is security and transparency. We need to ensure that employees' points and rewards are accurately tracked and that the system is fair and tamper-proof. That's where your Python skills will come in handy. We'll be relying on your expertise to develop robust backend systems and APIs that power the platform.

Jorge: Understood. I'm confident that my Python experience will be valuable here. Are there any particular libraries or frameworks that CHEETAH prefers for this type of project?

Djibril: Yes, we generally favor the Flask framework for building web APIs. It's lightweight and versatile. For the database layer, we often use PostgreSQL, known for its robustness and ability to handle complex data structures. As for your coding style, there are a few specific instructions I'd like you to follow.

Jorge: Of course. I'm all ears.

Djibril: Firstly, always add the '@validate' decorator from the 'pedantic' module to all your methods. This ensures that input validation is consistently applied, preventing a host of potential issues.

Jorge: Got it. I'll make sure to include the '@validate' decorator in all my method definitions.

Djibril: Excellent. We'll also be using Git for version control, so ensure that you're familiar with our branching strategy and pull request process. We take code quality seriously here at CHEETAH, and we want to set a high standard for the industry.

Jorge: I agree, and I'm happy to be a part of a company that values code quality. I'm familiar with Git, and I'll make sure to get up to speed with your specific processes. Anything else I should keep in mind?

Djibril: For now, that covers the main points. I'll provide you with some initial tasks to get you started, and we can schedule regular check-ins to discuss your progress and any questions you may have. Remember, I'm here to support you, so don't hesitate to reach out.

Jorge: Thank you, Djibril. I truly appreciate your guidance and support. I'm excited to dive into these tasks and contribute to the rewards platform. I'll make sure to follow the coding instructions and familiarise myself with the processes.

topic: Implementing a rewards and recognition program to motivate and engage employees
sessions.text:
Djibril: Jorge, it's been a pleasure witnessing your growth over the past few months. I wanted to touch base with you today about something that's crucial for team morale and productivity—our rewards and recognition program. We've discussed this briefly before, but I'd like to delve deeper and get your insights.

Jorge: Absolutely, Djibril. I'm glad we're revisiting this topic because employee recognition is essential for fostering a positive work environment. I've been thinking about some ideas we can implement to show our appreciation for the team's hard work.

Djibril: Fantastic! I believe you have a unique perspective, given your creative mindset. One of the things we want to achieve with this program is to encourage innovation and a willingness to take calculated risks. How do you think we can structure rewards or incentives to promote those values?

Jorge: That's an interesting question. I think we should consider recognizing employees who demonstrate an innovative approach to problem-solving or who propose creative solutions to challenges we face.  This could be a peer-nominated award, ensuring that everyone has a chance to recognize each other's contributions.

Djibril: I love the sound of that, Jorge! Encouraging peer recognition is an excellent way to foster a culture of appreciation and ensure that everyone feels empowered to celebrate each other's successes. Another aspect we want to focus on is consistent improvement and learning. How can we incentivize our team members to continuously develop their skills and stay engaged with the latest industry trends?

Jorge: Well, one idea could be to offer incentives for employees who pursue self-development initiatives.  Not only does this benefit the individual, but it also enhances the overall skill set of our team.

Djibril: Absolutely! Investing in our team's growth and providing tangible incentives for their efforts is vital. Now, I want your thoughts on something specific. What are your ideas for recognizing employees who take on mentorship roles and share their knowledge with others?

Jorge: Mentorship is a vital aspect of professional development, and recognizing our mentors is essential. We could introduce a "Mentor of the Quarter" award, where we showcase mentors who have gone above and beyond in supporting their mentees. This could be based on feedback from mentees, the impact of the mentorship on their work, and the overall dedication of the mentor. 

Djibril: Excellent! I think these ideas are a great starting point for building a robust rewards and recognition program. Remember, this is all about making our team feel valued and motivated. Your insights are invaluable, and I want you to know that your contributions are making a difference. 

Jorge: Thank you, Djibril. It means a lot to have this opportunity to share my thoughts and feel like I'm contributing to the team's culture and morale. I'm excited to see how we can implement these ideas and create a more engaging and rewarding work environment. 

Djibril: That's the spirit, Jorge! Your enthusiasm is infectious, and I'm confident that with your input, we'll be able to craft a program that our team will truly appreciate. Let's keep the momentum going and turn these ideas into actions! 

Jorge: Absolutely! I'll get started on drafting a more detailed proposal based on our discussion, and we can refine it together. It's exciting to be part of a company that values employee engagement so highly. 

Djibril: Fantastic! I'm proud of the work we're doing, and I'm sure that with your creativity and dedication, we'll take CHEETAH to new heights. Keep up the excellent work, Jorge! 

Jorge: Thank you, Djibril! I really appreciate your guidance and support. I'll make sure to deliver on these ideas.

topic: Travel arrangements and logistics for client meetings, conferences, and business trips
always end function argument names with '_x'
always use all UPPERCASE for class names
session_eval_query: function that merges two sorted lists
PyTorch model class that performs binary image classification
sessions.text:
Djibril: Hi Jorge, how are you doing today? 

Jorge: I'm good, thanks. How are you? 

Djibril: I'm great. So, I wanted to touch base with you regarding some upcoming travel plans and logistics for client meetings and conferences. Are you all set with your travel arrangements for the upcoming quarter? 

Jorge: Yes, mostly. I have a few trips planned already. I'll be attending the Web Development Conference in Seattle next month, and then I have a client meeting in Toronto the month after. I'm just finalizing a few details, but everything is on track. 

Djibril: That's great. These events are excellent opportunities for learning and networking. Make sure you take advantage of them. Now, regarding your travels, are there any specific preparations or logistics you need help with? It's important to plan these things in advance to ensure a smooth trip. 

Jorge: Actually, I wanted to talk to you about that. I'm not entirely sure what to expect at these conferences and meetings. I've attended a few in the past, but I want to make sure I'm prepared and represent CHEETAH well. Any advice on that front? 

Djibril: Absolutely. These events can vary, but there are some general guidelines you can follow. First, always bring business cards. You never know who you'll meet, and having a physical reminder of your connection can be valuable. Second, prepare an elevator pitch about yourself and CHEETAH. You want to be able to introduce yourself confidently and concisely. Lastly, don’t be afraid to join in on discussions and ask questions. Active participation will help you get the most out of these events. 

Jorge: That's really helpful, thank you. I'll make sure to prepare accordingly. 

Djibril: You're welcome. Now, switching gears a bit, I want to go over some coding standards and practices I'd like you to implement going forward. It's important that we maintain consistency across our codebases. So, from now on, I need you to ensure that you always end function argument names with '_x'. This will help us maintain a clear and consistent style. Also, when naming classes, use all uppercase letters. This is a standard we're implementing to improve readability and maintain consistency with our Python code. 

Jorge: Understood. I'll make sure to follow these instructions from now on. 

Djibril: Great. Consistency is key, and it'll make collaboration and code reviews much smoother. If you have any questions or need clarification on anything we've discussed, don't hesitate to reach out. 

Jorge: Will do. Thanks for your guidance and support, Djibril. 

Djibril: You're very welcome. That's what I'm here for. Let's touch base again soon to ensure everything is on track. 

Jorge: Sounds good. Have a great day! 

Djibril: You too!

topic: Happy hour events to foster better relationships between managers and employees
always end function argument names with '_f'

sessions.text:
Djibril: How are you settling in, Jorge? I know it can be a lot taking in all the company policies and procedures, but I'm here if you have any questions.

Jorge: I'm doing well, thanks. I've been enjoying my time here so far. The team has been great, and I'm learning a lot. I do have a question about something I've noticed. Have you attended the happy hour events? I saw them mentioned on the calendar.

Djibril: Yes, those are a great way to foster better relationships between managers and employees. It's a more casual setting where we can connect and discuss things outside of work. It helps build a positive company culture and improves communication. I try to attend as many as I can. They're usually a lot of fun!

Jorge: That's fantastic to hear! I've been meaning to go to one of those. I think building relationships with colleagues is crucial for a healthy work environment. It makes collaborating on projects much more enjoyable. I'll make sure to attend the next one. Are there any particular icebreakers or activities that are common at these events?

Djibril: Oh yes, there are usually some games or activities to get everyone relaxed and chatting. Sometimes we do trivia, other times it's more interactive things like two truths and a lie, or even just simple introduction games to get everyone familiar with each other. It's a great way to learn more about your colleagues and their interests outside of work.

Jorge: That sounds like a lot of fun! I'm definitely looking forward to the next one. Changing the subject a bit, I wanted to check in with you about some coding standards. I remember you mentioning some specific guidelines, and I wanted to make sure I was adhering to them properly.

Djibril: Absolutely. I want to emphasize the importance of consistency in our code. I've updated one of the previous instructions I gave you. From now on, I'd like you to end function argument names with '_f' and always end method names with '_md'. This will help us maintain a clear and uniform style throughout our codebases.

Jorge: Understood. I'll make sure to follow that naming convention from now on. Consistency is key, and I appreciate you keeping me updated with these standards. It helps me produce code that aligns with the team's expectations. Are there any other updates or adjustments I should be aware of?

Djibril: No, that's the only update for now. Just remember that these standards are important for our team's cohesion and efficiency. If you ever have any questions or need clarification on anything, don't hesitate to reach out. That's what I'm here for.

Jorge: Of course. Thank you so much for your guidance and support, Djibril. It means a lot to have a mentor who's so invested in my development. I'll make sure to apply these coding standards moving forward. I'll see you at the next happy hour, too!

Djibril: You're very welcome, Jorge. It's my pleasure to mentor you and see your growth here at CHEETAH. I'm always happy to help, and I'm glad to hear you'll be joining us at the next happy hour. They're a great opportunity to unwind and get to know your colleagues better. See you there!

topic: use a linux desktop as the main computer
sessions.text:
Djibril: Jorge, how are you settling in so far? Any initial hurdles with the new system? 

Jorge: It's going well, thanks. I'm getting used to the Linux desktop; it's quite different from what I'm used to, but I can see the benefits, especially for version control and collaboration. 

Djibril: Excellent! Linux is a powerful tool, and it's great that you're already seeing the upside. The learning curve can be steep, but mastering it will give you a solid foundation for your work here at CHEETAH. 

Jorge: Definitely. I've been playing around with some of the built-in tools and scripts, and I must say, it's an efficient environment once you get the hang of it. I'm curious, though, are there any specific Linux distributions or package managers that the team favors? 

Djibril: That's a good question. Here at CHEETAH, we mostly use Ubuntu as our Linux distribution of choice. It's user-friendly and has strong community support, which can be helpful when troubleshooting. As for package managers, we primarily work with APT, but it's also useful to be familiar with alternatives like Yum and Zypper, as you'll encounter them in different Linux ecosystems. 

Jorge: Makes sense. I've been meaning to dive into Ubuntu; it seems like a popular choice. Are there any particular configurations or tweaks that the team has found useful for our specific use case? 

Djibril: Absolutely. One of the strengths of Linux is its customizability. Many of us find it helpful to set up a development environment that suits our specific needs.  This way, you have easy access to everything you need, streamlining your workflow. 

Jorge: That sounds really useful. I tend to use a variety of tools depending on the project, so having them readily accessible would definitely speed up my processes. Are there any resources or guides you'd recommend for setting up such an environment? 

Djibril: Certainly. CHEETAH actually has an internal knowledge base with step-by-step guides on setting up your Linux environment, tailored to our specific needs. It covers everything from installing essential development packages to configuring your shell for enhanced productivity. I'll make sure to share the link with you so you can get started. 

Jorge: Awesome, that will be incredibly helpful. I'm looking forward to customizing my setup and really making it my own. 

Djibril: That's the spirit! And remember, if you have any questions or issues along the way, don't hesitate to reach out. That's what we're here for. The team is always happy to help, and we want to ensure you have all the tools you need to succeed. 

Jorge: Thanks so much, Djibril. I really appreciate your support and guidance. I'll definitely take you up on that offer if I run into any snags. 

Djibril: You're very welcome. That's what mentorship is all about. Now, speaking of support, let's also make sure you're acquainted with our team's best practices for collaboration and code review. We'll dive into that next to ensure you're set up for success when working with your colleagues. 

Jorge: Sounds like a plan! I'm all ears.

topic: never use a notebook for taking notes
sessions.text:
Djibril: Jorge, I've been meaning to talk to you about note-taking. I want you to forget about using a notebook from now on.

Jorge: Oh? Why is that, Djibril? I've always taken notes by hand; it helps me process information and it's easier to refer back to them.

Djibril: I understand that it might be a habit, but in our line of work, it's crucial that we digitize our notes. Not only does it make sharing and collaborating easier, but it also ensures that our thoughts and ideas are easily searchable and organized.

Jorge: That makes sense, especially for team projects. But I'm curious, what's the harm in keeping a notebook as well? I could always transcribe my notes later.

Djibril: Transcription takes time, and more often than not, it becomes a tedious task that gets pushed to the wayside. We want our notes to be accessible and useful, not tucked away in a drawer or buried under piles of paperwork.

Jorge: Okay, I see what you mean. I guess I've never thought about the drawbacks of physical note-taking in a professional setting. So, what tools or methods would you recommend for digital note-taking?

Djibril: Well, there are several options. You could use a simple text editor, but I'd recommend something more robust and flexible, like a Markdown editor. It allows you to format your notes, include code snippets, and even images.

Jorge: That sounds way more efficient than plain text. Are there any specific Markdown editors that you think are particularly good for this purpose?

Djibril: Definitely. One of my favorites is Typora. It has a clean interface and supports a wide range of formatting options. Plus, it's available on multiple platforms, so you can access your notes anywhere.

Jorge: Alright, I'll give Typora a try. I think it's time I modernize my note-taking methods. Thanks for the insight, Djibril. I'm always up for learning new ways to improve my workflow.

Djibril: Anytime, Jorge. It's important to adapt and embrace new tools, especially in our industry. Remember, the goal is to streamline your processes and make your work more efficient and shareable.

topic: Implementing a rewards and recognition program to motivate and engage employees
session_eval_query: Graph class with a method that computes the shortest path from one node to another
sessions.text:
Djibril: I wanted to circle back to our previous discussion about employee engagement and recognizing their achievements. We've been working on implementing a rewards and recognition program, and I think it's time to put those ideas into action.

Jorge: Absolutely! I think it's a great initiative, and I'm keen to see how we can make it work. It's an important aspect of keeping our team motivated and engaged.

Djibril: Exactly. We want to create an environment where employees feel valued and encouraged to continue performing at their best. A simple recognition program can go a long way in fostering a positive company culture.

Jorge: Definitely! It aligns with our company values of innovation and risk-taking as well. Recognizing and rewarding employees for their contributions can inspire others to follow suit.

Djibril: I'm glad we're on the same page. Now, regarding the implementation, I've been thinking about a few key elements. First, we should ensure that the program is inclusive and accessible to all employees, regardless of their role or tenure. Everyone should have an equal opportunity to be recognized and rewarded.

Jorge: That's an important point. Maybe we can have different categories of recognition, so that we're acknowledging achievements in various forms, whether it's innovation, teamwork, customer service, or leadership.

Djibril: That's a great suggestion! By having multiple categories, we can showcase the diverse talents and contributions within our company. Now, aside from the program structure, we also need to consider the actual rewards. They should be meaningful and something that our employees truly value.

Jorge: Right, the rewards should definitely be worth striving for. Perhaps we can offer a mix of tangible rewards, like gift cards or company merchandise, and intangible rewards, such as public recognition, extra vacation days, or even a mentorship opportunity with a senior leader.

Djibril: Those are excellent ideas, Jorge. I think a combination of tangible and intangible rewards will definitely appeal to our employees and motivate them. Now, as we continue to develop this program, I also want to touch on another topic: coding standards.

Jorge: Of course, I'm always eager to improve my coding practices.

Djibril: Going forward, I want you to update your coding style to end all method names with '_ud'. This is a new standard we're implementing to maintain consistency across the team.

Jorge: Understood, Djibril. I'll make sure to follow this naming convention from now on.

Djibril: Great! Consistency is key in maintaining readable and maintainable code, so I appreciate your attention to detail. Now, feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns about this new standard, or anything else for that matter. My door is always open.

Jorge: Will do, thanks for the guidance as always. I'll get started on updating my code accordingly. It's a small change but an important one for uniformity.

topic: Creating a knowledge-sharing platform to facilitate learning and collaboration among employees
session_eval_query: function that returns the longest common prefix string in a list of strings
Graph class with a method that computes the shortest path from one node to another
sessions.text:
Djibril: Knowledge-sharing platforms are a great way to foster a culture of learning and collaboration. We want to create a space where employees can easily share their expertise and learn from one another. This will not only enhance our overall skill set but also improve communication and teamwork. 

Jorge: Absolutely. I think this is a fantastic idea. It aligns with my belief in the power of community and the value of diverse perspectives. By sharing knowledge, we can spark new ideas and innovative solutions. 

Djibril: Indeed. And it's a great way to recognize and utilize the talent we have within the company. Now, let's discuss some of the technical aspects. I want to emphasize the importance of clear and concise documentation. Always use docstrings in your functions to provide a brief description, explain the inputs and outputs, and offer examples when necessary. This practice will make your code more readable and maintainable.

Jorge: Understood. I'll make sure to incorporate docstrings consistently.

Djibril: Great. Also, going forward, I want you to update your naming convention for methods. End all method names with '_a'.  This is to maintain consistency with our team's coding standards.

Jorge: Noted. I'll keep that in mind for future coding tasks. I'll end method names with '_a' from now on.

Djibril: That's great, Jorge. By adopting these practices, we can ensure that our code is not only functional but also adheres to the highest standards of readability and maintainability. 

Jorge: I appreciate the guidance. These practices will definitely improve the quality of my code and make it more accessible to my colleagues. 

Djibril: Exactly. And don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. We're all here to support each other and improve our craft. 

Jorge: Thank you, Djibril. I feel fortunate to have your mentorship and the collaborative environment at CHEETAH.

topic: Launching diversity and inclusion initiatives to create a more equitable and inclusive workplace
sessions.text:
Djibril: Hi Jorge, how are you doing today?

Jorge: I'm good, thanks. It's been an interesting few weeks, learning the ropes and getting to know the team. I feel like I'm settling in.

Djibril: That's great to hear. CHEETAH prides itself on its diverse and inclusive culture, and we want to ensure that all our employees feel supported and empowered. Have you had a chance to familiarize yourself with our diversity and inclusion initiatives?

Jorge: Yes, definitely. I've read through the company's D&I statement and the various employee resource groups we have. It's encouraging to see the emphasis CHEETAH places on these issues. I think it's important, especially in the tech industry, where these topics haven't always been prioritized.

Djibril: Absolutely. We believe that a diverse and inclusive workforce drives innovation and helps us better understand our customers' needs. That's why we're always looking for ways to enhance our D&I efforts. I wanted to talk to you today about an idea I've been discussing with the management team. We're considering launching a mentorship program specifically aimed at underrepresented groups within the company.

Jorge: That sounds like a fantastic idea! Mentorship can be so valuable, especially for those who might face unique challenges in the workplace due to their identity. I think it could really help foster a sense of community and support.

Djibril: Exactly. We want to create a safe and nurturing environment for our mentees, where they can develop their skills and build their network. As a mentor, I've seen firsthand how these relationships can impact someone's career trajectory. We're hoping that by providing this opportunity, we can help retain talented individuals and ensure they thrive here at CHEETAH.

Jorge: I completely agree. It's also a great way to promote knowledge sharing across different teams and departments. I'm sure many employees would be eager to participate, both as mentors and mentees.

Djibril: Indeed, and that's where your input comes in. As someone with a strong creative mindset, I'd like your thoughts on how we can structure this program to make it engaging and accessible. We want to encourage participation while also ensuring that the mentorship pairs are well-matched and beneficial for both parties.

Jorge: For sure. I think a good starting point would be to have an opt-in process where employees can express their interest and specify their expectations and goals. This way, we can gather information about their mentorship style preferences and areas they want to focus on. Then, we can carefully match them with mentors or mentees who align with their interests and can offer valuable insights.

Djibril: That's a great suggestion. An opt-in process ensures that participants are committed and enthusiastic, which is crucial for the success of the program. We can also provide resources and guidelines to help structure the mentorship relationships and ensure they remain productive and beneficial.

Jorge: Absolutely. And maybe we can also incorporate some social events or networking opportunities specifically for the participants. This way, they can build community and feel more connected to the program and each other.

Djibril: That's an excellent idea, Jorge. It's important to foster those connections and create a sense of belonging. We can definitely explore ways to bring mentees and mentors together outside of their one-on-one meetings. Your insights are very valuable, and I think this program is going to make a real difference. I'm glad to have your perspective as we shape these initiatives.

Jorge: Thank you, Djibril. I'm happy to contribute, and I think this conversation highlights CHEETAH's commitment to diversity and inclusion. I'm excited to see how this mentorship program takes shape and the positive impact it will have.

Djibril: Absolutely, and we're grateful to have your enthusiasm and creative thinking behind it. We'll keep you posted on the progress, and please do share any further ideas or suggestions. Together, we can make CHEETAH an even more inclusive and innovative workplace.

Jorge: Definitely! I'm looking forward to it, and I'm glad to be a part of these initiatives.

topic: never use a formatter when writing code

sessions.text:
Djibril:  I wanted to talk to you about code formatting. It's important to keep our code base consistent and easy to read for the whole team. 

Jorge: Yeah, I've been trying to follow the style guidelines we have in place. I usually use a formatter to help with that. It saves time and ensures consistency. 

Djibril: Formatters can be helpful, but I want you to try something different. From now on, I need you to refrain from using them. It's important that you format your code manually. 

Jorge: Oh, I never thought about avoiding formatters. Why is that? It seems like extra work and I could make mistakes. 

Djibril: I understand your concern, but manually formatting your code has several benefits. First, it improves your familiarity with the code itself. When you manually indent, align, and structure your code, you engage more deeply with the logic and structure. It becomes easier to spot errors or inconsistencies. 

Jorge: That makes sense. It's like proofreading a document. You catch mistakes more easily when you read it aloud or review it manually. 

Djibril: Exactly! It's a similar concept. Another advantage is that you develop a better sense of ownership and responsibility for your code. When you invest time and effort into crafting and refining it, you tend to take more pride in your work. It encourages you to write cleaner, more efficient code from the start. 

Jorge: That's a good point. I can see how that would improve the quality of my code. So, what specific steps should I take? 

Djibril: Well, start by disabling any formatters you've been using. Then, take the time to review the style guidelines we have. Pay attention to indentation, spacing, naming conventions, and any other specifics. 

Jorge: Alright, I'll give it a shot. I guess it'll take some time to adjust, but I can see the benefits. 

Djibril: Great! It might feel a bit tedious at first, but I promise it'll pay off in the long run. And remember, if you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. That's what I'm here for. 

Jorge: Thanks, Djibril. I appreciate your guidance and support. I'll let you know how it goes. 

Djibril: Sounds good, Jorge. We're all CHEETAHs here, so don't hesitate to roar if you need anything! 

Jorge:  [Laughs] Will do!
